_exec_summary.SummaryText:
OLS Energy-Agnews
RMP for Anhydrous Ammonia


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

OLS Energy-Agnews, Inc. of San Jose generates electric power by burning natural gas in a gas turbine. As part of its emissions control it injects diluted ammonia vapor into the turbine exhaust, and thus reduces NOx emissions.  The ammonia is stored in anhydrous form in a 12,000gal. storage tank, which is well anchored to prevent earthquake damage.  The ammonia is piped from there in liquid form to a vaporizer where it is turned into gas.  From there it goes to an accumulator.  From the accumulator it is mixed with air and injected into the turbine exhaust stream in the heat recovery steam generator.

 The facility has good preventative maintenance procedures and emergency response planning.  As part of the emergency response planning the facility has an Emergency Action Plan, which addresses every type of emergency or release the facility could expect.  The release of ammonia is specifically covered in the Emergency Action Plan (EAP).  The EAP for ammonia contains all emergency contact numbers as well as operator safety and mitigation procedures.   As part of the facility?s accidental release prevention, training is conducted annually for employees on Hazardous Material Handling, Hazard Communication, Emergency Response, Spill Prevention, safe operation, maintenance, and emergency procedures.  There is a specific procedure for delivery and handling of anhydrous ammonia, which includes specific operational guidelines as well as emergency actions.

The facility has carried out a Process Hazards Analysis (PHA).  As a result or the PHA some safety improvements were made to the ammonia system and procedures.  These improvements are as follows:  1) Installation of relief valves between isolation valves on the piping between the unloading rack and the tank, 2) Conducted a seismic evaluation ? installed flexible lines from the tank to the supply pipe, fill pipe, and the vapor return pipe, 3) Plan to install a

dditional vertical and horizontal support on the ammonia piping system by June 2000, 4) Installed emergency shut-off valves to isolate all three pipes coming from the ammonia tank, 5) Modified delivery procedures to take deliveries with and additional operator present during shift change on Saturday mornings, 6) Conducted an ammonia release during a delivery drill with Cisco Systems ERT and the San Jose Fire Department.  

In order to limit the distance of a release, the facility has identified or added the following:  1) If there is a leak on the ammonia injection skid, ammonia flow to the HRSG can be increased to decrease pressure until the leak can be isolated, 2) Emergency shut-off valves were installed to minimize a leak in any piping downstream of the ammonia storage tank, 3) An extra operator was added during a delivery to increase safety and decrease response time in the event of an accident.  

OLS Energy-Agnews, Inc. has had no ammonia related accidents or releases in the last five years.  Additionally, the facility has had no ammonia related accidents in its operational history beginning December 1990.

The facility modeled two off-site consequence analyses.  The first was the worst case scenario that consisted of a full release of the ammonia storage tank, which is 12000 gallons or 61680 lbs. over 10 minutes.  This scenario had a toxic endpoint radius of 8.1 miles.  The second was an alternative release scenario that consisted of a hole in an unloading hose or pipe that was 0.4275 inches in diameter.  The release was 804.9 gallons or 4137 lbs. over 10 minutes that had a toxic endpoint of 0.41 miles.  

The facility has completed a Risk Management Plan and is actively implementing the RMP. The facility is in full compliance with all provisions of its RMP.
